awd_titl_txt: SGER:  Are Viruses a Significant Component of Dissolved DNA Marine Environment
awd_abstract_narration: The existence of dissolved DNA in the marine environment has been               well documented. Recently, viruses have been shown to be an                     important biological component of the dissolved fraction of                     seawater.It is not known what proportion of the dissolved DNA is                truly soluble DNA or DNA encapsulated within a virus particle.                  Differentiation and quantitation of the soluble DNA and the                     intact virions in the environment is important for both                         ecological and genetic reasons. From the ecological perspective,                soluble DNA is a form of nucleic acid precursors for                            macromolecular biosynthesis. Viruses no doubt contribute to                     dissolved DNA and organic carbon production and control the                     microbial population by lysing their hosts. Dr. Paul will                       develop methods to separate and quantitate viral particles from                 free DNA in the water column. This study will lead to methodology               for the rapid isolation of viruses for future study.

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: University of South Florida Department of Marine Science
